courseDescription: General introduction to the naval service.  Particular emphasis placed on the mission, organization, regulations and broad warfare components of the Navy and Marine Corps.  Includes customs, discipline, courtesies, leadership, core values and shipboard nomenclatures.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adherence to naval service customs and courtesies
Effective communication within naval service regulations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization in alignment with naval service regulations

courseTitle: Naval Sea Power and Maritime Affairs
courseDescription: The study of the evolution of the major world naval and maritime nations. The role of American naval and maritime affairs in the rivalries of the great world powers during the colonial period, the spread of revolutionary movements, and the era of civil and international conflicts in the 19th and 20th centuries.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Written and verbal communication of historical events
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project planning and management in historical research

courseDescription: Covers basic military formations, drill movements, commands, customs, courtesies, honors and inspection.  Lecture and discussion topics include security, equal opportunity and military justice.  First year Naval Science students only.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of military customs and courtesies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Verbal communication in a military context

courseDescription: Continues basic military formations, drill movements, commands, customs, courtesies, honors and inspections.  Lecture and discussion topics include cruise preparation, safety education, administration, security, equal opportunity and military justice.  First year Naval Science students only.

Familiarizes students with types, structure and purpose of naval engineering systems, propulsion systems, auxiliary power systems, electrical systems and ship control.  Ship design and stability characteristics are examined.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of ship design and stability characteristics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to evaluate and analyze ship design
Ability to troubleshoot problems in naval engineering systems

courseDescription: Introduction to theory and principles of operation of naval weapons systems.  Covers types of weapons and fire control systems, capabilities/limitations, theory of target acquisition, identification and tracking, trajectory principles and basics of naval ordnance.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to identify and track targets
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing capabilities and limitations of weapon systems
Application of theory for target acquisition
Analysis and application of trajectory principles

courseDescription: Covers military formations, drill movements, commands, customs, courtesies, honors and inspections.  Lecture/discussion topics include cruise preparation/evaluation, security, administration and military justice.  Second year Naval Science students only.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and following customs and courtesies

courseDescription: Military formations, drill movements, commands, customs, courtesies, honors and inspections.  Lecture and discussion topics include cruise preparation and evaluation, safety, administration, security, equal opportunity and military justice.  Second year Naval Science students only.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of military justice
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Respect for and adherence to military customs and courtesies
Promotion of equal opportunity within a military context
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in the context of military administration and security
Analyzing situations under the scope of military justice
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ensuring safety and security in a military organization

courseDescription: In-depth study of piloting including theory, principles and procedures.  Includes use of charts, visual and electronic aids, and theory and operation of compasses.  Other topics include tides, currents, effects of wind and weather, and nautical rules of the road.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of Wind and Weather Effects on Navigation

courseDescription: Relative motion vector-analysis theory, relative motion problems, formation tactics, and ship employment.  Also includes an introduction to naval operations and operations analysis, ship behavior and characteristics in maneuvering, applied aspects of ship handling, and afloat communications.  Concepts in naval leadership and naval operations reinforced through case studies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of ship behavior and characteristics in maneuvering

courseDescription: Explores the basic concepts for understanding the operational art of warfare from the beginning of recorded history to the present.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of military strategy and tactics

courseDescription: Military formations, drill movements, commands, customs, courtesies, honors and inspections.  Lecture/discussion topics include cruise preparation and evaluation, security and military justice. Third year Naval Science students only.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of naval customs and courtesies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Cultural competence in military customs and courtesies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and application of military justice

courseDescription: Military formations, drill movements, commands, customs, courtesies, honors and inspections.  Lecture and discussion topics include cruise preparation and evaluation, safety, administration, security, equal opportunity and military justice.  Third year Naval Science students only.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and application of military customs and courtesies
Proper execution of honors and inspections

courseDescription: The fundamentals of the managerial process (planning, organization, directing, and controlling) are considered in their relationship to the effectiveness of naval organization and readiness.  Coverage includes human resources management, naval personnel management, material management and administration of division discipline.
Capstone course, designed to equip the student with the critical thinking skills to address moral and ethical dilemmas frequently faced by naval officers.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Decision-making under moral and ethical considerations
Navigating ethical challenges in leadership roles

courseDescription: Broad aspects of warfare and their interactions with maneuver warfare doctrine. Focus on the United States Marine Corps as the premier maneuver warfare fighting institution. Historical influences on current tactical, operational, and strategic implications of maneuver warfare practices. Case studies. Enrollment preference to NROTC students.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting and communicating tactical, operational, and strategic implications
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing current warfare practices based on historical influences
Critical evaluation of warfare tactics and strategies

courseDescription: Covers military formations, drills, commands, customs, courtesies, honors and inspections.  Lecture/discussion topics include precommissioning preparation, administration, equal opportunity, safety and military justice.  Fourth year Naval Science students only.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adherence to military customs and courtesies
Interpersonal communication within a military context
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation and application of military justice
Risk assessment and safety protocol adherence

courseDescription: Military formations, drill movements, commands, customs, courtesies, honors and inspections.  Lecture and discussion topics include precommissioning preparation, safety, administration, security, equal opportunity and military justice.  Fourth year Naval Science students only.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of military formations and drills
Knowledge of military customs, courtesies, and honors
Understanding of military administration and security
Understanding of equal opportunity and military justice
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to give and follow commands
Promotion of equal opportunity within a team
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Promotion of equal opportunity within a team
